summary: Collect quality metrics for a set of intervals

arguments.name: --baitsfile
arguments.fulltext: List of baits to distinguish untargeted intervals from those that are targeted but not covered

arguments.summary: minimum coverage to be considered sequenceable
arguments.name: --coveragethreshold
arguments.fulltext:
The coverage of a missing interval may determine whether or not an interval is sequenceable. A low coverage will
 trigger gc content, mapping, base qualities and other checks to figure out why this interval was deemed
 unsequenceable.

arguments.summary: upper and lower bound for an interval to be considered high/low GC content
arguments.name: --gcthreshold
arguments.fulltext:
This value will be used to determine whether or not an interval had too high or too low GC content to be
 sequenced. This is only applied if there was not enough data in the interval.

arguments.summary: minimum interval length to be considered
arguments.name: --intervalsizethreshold
arguments.fulltext:
Intervals that are too small generate biased analysis. For example an interval of size 1 will have GC content
 1 or 0. To avoid misinterpreting small intervals, all intervals below this threshold will be ignored in the
 interpretation.

arguments.summary: minimum mapping quality for it to be considered usable
arguments.name: --mappingthreshold
arguments.fulltext: An average mapping quality above this value will determine the interval to be mappable.

arguments.summary: An output file created by the walker.  Will overwrite contents if file exists
arguments.name: --out
arguments.fulltext: A single GATKReport table with the qualifications on why the intervals passed by the -L argument were missing.

arguments.summary: minimum base quality for it to be considered usable
arguments.name: --qualthreshold
arguments.fulltext:
An average base quality above this value will rule out the possibility of context specific problems with the
 sequencer.

arguments.name: --targetsfile
arguments.fulltext:
List of targets used in the experiment. This file will be used to calculate the distance your missing
 intervals are to the targets (usually exons). Typically this is your hybrid selection targets file
 (e.g. Agilent exome target list)

description:
This tool collects the following metrics:

  • Average Base Quality
  • Average Mapping Quality
  • Average Depth
  • GC Content
  • Position in the target (Integer.MIN_VALUE if no overlap)
  • Length of the overlapping target (zero if no overlap)
  • Coding Sequence / Intron (optional)
  • Length of the uncovered interval

It is meant to be run on a set of intervals that have been identified as problematic in earlier stages of quality control and are considered "missing" from the sequence dataset.

Input

A reference file (for GC content), the input bam file (for base and mapping quality calculation), the missing intervals (in the -L), the baits/targets used to sequence (in the -targets) and a bed file with the coding sequence intervals of the genome (in the -cds).

Output

GC content, distance from the end of the target, coding sequence intersection, mapping and base quality averages and average depth per "missing" interval.

Usage example

 java -jar GenomeAnalysisTK.jar \
   -T QualifyMissingIntervals \
   -R reference.fasta \
   -I input.bam \
   -o output.grp \
   -L input.intervals \
   -cds cds.intervals \
   -targets targets.intervals
name: QualifyMissingIntervals
